tweets.classification

Class classification

  • java.lang.Object
    • tweets.classification.classification

  • @Controller
public class classification
extends Object
    classification is the class responsible for Tweet Classification.

    Tweets are classified into risks, benefits, and neutral tweets (R, B, N) and then saved into the MySQL database. A J48 classifier is used for classification. Filters are applied to the data so that the data is suitable for classification. Training data is used to train the classifier before classifying all of the tweets.

    Author:
    Dalia Mostafa

        public classification()

    • Method Detail

      • classify

        @CrossOrigin(origins="http://localhost:63342")
 @RequestMapping(value="/class")
 @ResponseBody
public void classify()
                                                                                                             throws Exception
        This is the method which classifies tweets into the three categories (risk, benefit, and neutral).
        First, it gets all the tweets from the database, and sends them to getTweetsandPreprocess() so that the tweets and training tweets are suitable for building the classifier and classification. The training tweets are saved to an ARFF file, and an WEKA instance is obtained from this file. Suitable filters are applied to the training tweet instance using the applyFiltersToTrainingSet method and the smote method. A J48 classifier is created and built using the training tweets' instance.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • getTweetsAndPreprocess

        public void getTweetsAndPreprocess()
                            throws Exception
        This method is responsible for preprocessing the tweets and training tweets so that they could be used efficiently.
        All punctuation is removed from the data, as well as mentions and surrounding words upon retweeting. (RT @ ...). The number of each class in training tweets is calculated so that the SMOTE algorithm could be later applied to avoid class imbalance issues.
        The Tweets are written to CSV and ARFF files to be later used by the WEKA classifier. A subset of 1000 tweets is written into each file to ensure that WEKA can handle the sizes of the files.
        Throws:
        Exception

        data - The instance that will be processed
        training - This attribute is only significant in case of the StringToWordVector method when processing the tweets so that the word vectors of the tweets could be matched to the training tweets.
        Returns:
        Throws:

      • applyFiltersToTrainingSet

        public static weka.core.Instances applyFiltersToTrainingSet(weka.core.Instances data,
                                                            weka.core.Instances training)
                                                     throws Exception
        This method applies all of the suitable filters to an instance of training tweets.
        The filters applied include StringToWordVector to the content of the tweets, NominalToString
        Parameters:
        data - The training data that is to be processed
        training - The training data that is to be processed
        Returns:
        instance after applying different filters.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • smote

        public static weka.core.Instances smote(weka.core.Instances data)
                                 throws Exception
        This method applies the SMOTE algorithm to the data. The SMOTE algorithm is a smart solution for the class imbalance problem in mahcine learning.
        The algorithm increases the two classes with the least amount of tweets.
        Parameters:
        data - The data that the smote algorithm will be applied to
        Returns:
        data after the SMOTE algorithm is applied
        Throws:
        Exception
